label: Timer
info: Send the output of a `suncalc` node once per minute to the _Theme_ and _Time of Day_ subflows (q.v.) The output of each subflow is sent as a retained MQTT message to drive lighting and window covering automation.

meta.author: parasaurolophus <apps@rader.us>
meta.desc: Make a HomeKit switch simulate a button

name: Hue Send
info:
Send a message to the API (version 2) on a given Hue Bridge.

See <https://developers.meethue.com/develop/hue-api-v2/> for details.

# Configuration

`ADDRESS` environment variable is the bridge's IP address.

`KEY` environment variable is the client access token for the message.

# Input

`msg.topic` is the API URI, e.g. `/resource`, `/room/0ca8f049-7ac9-4872-8069-4770834e4f11` etc.

`msg.payload` is the message body, if any.

`msg.method` is the HTTP request method, e.g. `GET`, `PUT` etc.

# Outputs

If successful, the HTTP response will be sent as a parsed JSON object from output 1.

A standard Node-RED error message will be sent on output 2 if the `http request` node throws an exception.

meta.author: parasaurolophus <apps@rader.us>
meta.desc: Send a command to the Hue Bridge API

name: Hue Access Token
info:
Use the Hue Bridge API to create a client access token.

**Invoke this subflow within 30 seconds of pressing the button on top of the bridge. Watch the debug console output to see the response. If successful, you will see the generated key among the response payload's properties.**

See <https://developers.meethue.com/develop/hue-api-v2/getting-started/> for details.

# Configuration

`ADDRESS` environment variable is the bridge's IP address.

`USERNAME` environment variable is the client "user name" for which a key is being requested.

# Input

Incoming message is ignored.

# Outputs

The HTTP response will be sent as a parsed JSON object. If successful, look for the value of the `msg.payload.success.username` property in the output. That is the string you should use as the access token header in all subsequent Hue Bridge API request messages.

meta.author: parasaurolophus <apps@rader.us>
meta.desc: Invoke the Hue Bridge API for registering a client

name: Hue SSE
info:
**Depends on [node-red-contrib-sse-client](https://flows.nodered.org/node/node-red-contrib-sse-client) (see <https://flows.nodered.org/node/node-red-contrib-sse-client>) which must be installed before this subflow.**

Subscribe to the SSE message stream from a given Hue Bridge. Forward received events as retained MQTT messages. Along the way, persist in node context a cumulative representation of the values of all the attributes of each message as it passes through. Pass along the updated, cumulative payload. This is a work around for a number of crippling defects in the design of the Hue Bridge API V2.

This subflow is intended to be used in concert with complementary logic when `GET` and `PUT` API entry points are invoked. The net effect is that over time a comprehensive representation of the instantaneous state of all the Hue devices and other resources for a given bridge is built up as the values of a collection of retained MQTT messages, kept in sync with an in-memory snapshot of that representation in this subflow's context storage (really, the node context storage of a particular `function` node within this subflow).

See <https://developers.meethue.com/develop/hue-api-v2/core-concepts/#events> for details.

# Configuration

`ADDRESS` environment variable is the bridge's IP address.

`KEY` environment variable is the client access token for the message.

`TOPIC` environment variable is the base MQTT topic to prepend to each output message as events are received. Each output message will have a complete topic string of the form `${TOPIC}/<uri>`, where `<uri>` is based on the type of event. Such topic strings are designed to align with the URI's for corresponding `GET` and `PUT` API messages. This allows the use of retained MQTT in a "closed loop" for persistence, synchronizing the displayed state of dashboard controls and so on.

# Input

`msg.topic` is passed through from the input message, for maintaining a "closed loop" of Hue device or other resource state that will be persisted using flow context in sync with retained MQTT messages.

`msg.payload` is the updated state of some device or other resource received through retained MQTT messages.

# Output

A stream of messages with MQTT topics and payloads that correspond to events received from the Hue Bridge. The output messages have `msg.retain` set to `true` so that the state of each device or other resource will be persisted by the MQTT broker.

# Side Effects

A cumulative snapshot of the complete state of each Hue device or other resource is maintained in flow context as this subflow processes individual SSE messages. That internal snapshot is also updated on receipt of corresponding retained MQTT messages. Thus, this subflow acts as an in-memory representation of the external state of Hue hardware and keeps that in-memory in sync across reboots, using the MQTT broker as a persistence mechanism as well as a communication medium. All of this is designed as a work around for crippling defects in the overall design of the Hue Bridge API that make it challenging to use for its intended purpose without a great deal of pre- and post-processing of SSE messages and other API calls.

meta.author: parasaurolophus <apps@rader.us>
meta.desc: Forward Philips Hue Bridge SSE messages to MQTT

name: PowerView Rooms
info:
Use the _Hunter Douglas PowerView_® hub API to get metadata for rooms.


See <https://motorisation.hde.nl/hd/powerview/general-guides/API/> for details.

# Configuration

The `ADDRESS` environment variable must be configured with the IP address of the hub.

# Input

All input message properties are ignored but care should be taken not to pass any through that could affect the behavior of a `http request` node in unintended ways.

# Output

HTTP response from the hub.

meta.author: parasaurolophus <apps@rader.us>
meta.desc: Get the room configuration from a PowerView hub

name: PowerView Scenes
info:
Use the _Hunter Douglas PowerView_® hub API to get metadata for scenes.


See <https://motorisation.hde.nl/hd/powerview/general-guides/API/> for details.

# Configuration

The `ADDRESS` environment variable must be configured with the IP address of the hub.

# Input

All input message properties are ignored but care should be taken not to pass any through that could affect the behavior of a `http request` node in unintended ways.

# Output

HTTP response from the hub.

meta.author: parasaurolophus <apps@rader.us>
meta.desc: Get the scene configuration from a PowerView hub

name: PowerView Set Scene
info:
Use the _Hunter Douglas PowerView_® hub API to activate a given window shade scene.


See <https://motorisation.hde.nl/hd/powerview/general-guides/API/> for details.

# Configuration

The `ADDRESS` environment variable must be configured with the IP address of the hub.

# Input

`msg.payload` containing the id of the scene to activate.

All other input message properties are ignored but care should be taken not to pass any through that could affect the behavior of a `http request` node in unintended ways.

# Output

HTTP response from the hub.

# Side Effects

If successful, the window shades will move to the settings defined by the specified scene as configured using the _PowerView_® mobile app.

meta.author: parasaurolophus <apps@rader.us>
meta.desc: Extract Hue metadata used to author dashboard and HomeKit integration

name: Time of Day
info:
Determine the time of day based on the latest `suncalc` event. This will be one of the following values:

| `msg.payload` | Time of Day |
|:-:|-|
| `morning` | Sunrise to 5 hours after sunrise |
| `midday` | 5 hours after sunrise to 5 hours before sunset |
| `afternoon` | 5 hours before sunset to sunset |
| `evening` | Sunset to bedtime |
| `night` | Bedtime to sunrise |

"Bedtime" is configurable using the dashboard. The actual time at which `evening` transitions to `night` varies from day to day by adding a randomly generated offset from 30 minutes before to 30 minutes after the configured time. A new random offset is generated each morning.

name: Theme
info:
Use the most recent `suncalc` event to determine the theme for lighting automation based on the current month and day. This will be one of the following:

| `msg.payload` | Current Date                     |
|:-------------:|----------------------------------|
| `tribal`      | July 1 - 4 |
| `spooky`      | Any day in October               |
| `jolly`       | Any day in December              |
| `standard`    | Any other day                    |

name: Filter Timer Events
info:
Pass messages through if and only if all of the following conditions are met:

1. `global.enableAutomation` is `true`
2. Payload has changed since last event
3. This is not the first event since the flow was started

name: Set Global Bedtime
info: Set `global.bedtime` to the value of `msg.payload`

name: Get Global Bedtime
info: Set `msg.payload` to the current value of `global.bedtime.minutes`

name: Yard Evening
info: Set `msg.theme` to the current value of `global.theme`. Select which output on which to forward the message based on the current theme.

info: Persist in node context a cumulative representation of the values of all the attributes of each message as it passes through. Pass along the updated, cumulative payload. This is a work around for a number of crippling defects in the Hue Bridge API V2.

name: atStart
func:
let now = Date.now()

node.status({text: now, fill: 'yellow', shape: 'dot'})
msg.payload = now
return msg
info:
Send a message when the flow starts and, optionally, at a fixed interval thereafter.

Subsequent messages can also be generated on demand by sending anything to this function node's input. In the latter case, the input message is ignored and the triggered message will have the same content as those generated by timers.

Use in subflows where `trigger` nodes are not allowed.

| Environment Variable | Default   | Description                                                                       |
|----------------------|-----------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| `DELAY`              | `1000`    | Milliseconds to wait at start before sending a message                            |
| `INTERVAL`           | `0`       | If greater than 0, milliseconds to wait between subsequent messages               |
| `TOPIC`              | `"timer"` | Value for `msg.topic`                                                             |
| `PAYLOAD`            | `null`    | Value for `msg.topic`; if `null`, then payload will contain the current timestamp |
